name: Egyptian Hieroglyphics
driver_note: Christianity suppressed Egyptian religion. Last hieroglyphic inscription 394 CE. Language died with the priests.
threat: Egyptian religion banned under Theodosius I (391 CE). Temples closed. Priests who could read hieroglyphics died without successors. 1,400 years of silence.
quantity_lost: Oral traditions, religious practices, pronunciation. But texts on stone survived unread.
saved_how: Rosetta Stone found during Napoleon's Egyptian campaign (1799). Jean-François Champollion deciphered hieroglyphics (1822) using Greek parallel text.
what_remains_at_risk: Fully recovered. Hieroglyphics now taught in universities. Thousands of texts translated.
sources: Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone (Richard Parkinson)

name: Mesopotamian Cuneiform Tablets
driver_note: Nineveh destroyed by Babylonians/Medes (612 BCE). Library buried in ruins. Clay tablets survived where papyrus would have burned.
threat: Library of Ashurbanipal destroyed when Nineveh fell. 30,000+ tablets buried under rubble for 2,500 years.
quantity_lost: Some fragmentary, many still untranslated. But core texts survived.
saved_how: Clay tablets preserved by fire and burial. Excavated by Layard, Rassam and others (1840s-1850s). Cuneiform deciphered by Rawlinson, Hincks, and others.
what_remains_at_risk: Massive backlog of untranslated tablets. Ongoing looting of Iraqi sites. ISIS destroyed some sites but tablets in museums are safe.
sources: The Epic of Gilgamesh (Andrew George translation)

name: Dead Sea Scrolls
driver_note: Hidden by Qumran community during Roman siege of Jerusalem (66-73 CE). Same conquest pattern as Jewish-Roman Wars destruction.
threat: Roman destruction of Jewish communities. Scrolls hidden in caves near Qumran. Nearly rotted away over 1900 years.
quantity_lost: Many fragmentary. Some used as kindling by Bedouins before value understood.
saved_how: Bedouin shepherd found first scrolls in cave (1947). Archaeological excavations recovered more (1947-1956). Fragments still being pieced together.
what_remains_at_risk: Some fragments in private hands. Ongoing disputes over access and publication. Climate-controlled storage essential.
sources: The Complete Dead Sea Scrolls in English (Penguin)

name: Nag Hammadi Library
driver_note: Gnostic texts hidden from Christian persecution. Bishop Athanasius ordered destruction of 'heretical' books (367 CE). Same purification logic as later book burnings.
threat: Christian suppression of Gnostic Christianity. Texts buried ~367 CE to avoid destruction. Nearly lost to decay and ignorance.
quantity_lost: Some pages used as kindling before value understood. One codex sold and burned for fuel.
saved_how: Egyptian farmer found sealed jar while digging (1945). Texts eventually reached scholars. Published 1970s-80s.
what_remains_at_risk: Now preserved. Transformed understanding of early Christianity and Gnosticism.

name: Timbuktu Manuscripts
driver_note: Ansar Dine/al-Qaeda destroyed 4,000 manuscripts as 'idolatrous'. Same purification logic as historical religious destructions.
threat: Islamist occupation of Timbuktu. 4,000+ manuscripts burned. Mausoleums destroyed.
saved_how: Librarians and locals smuggled 350,000+ manuscripts to Bamako in rice sacks, donkey carts, and river boats before and during occupation.
what_remains_at_risk: Many manuscripts still in private family collections. Digitization incomplete. Climate and insects threaten unpreserved texts.
sources: The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu (Joshua Hammer, 2016)

name: Tibetan Buddhist Texts
driver_note: Cultural Revolution targeted religion as 'feudal superstition'. Same ideological purification as other Communist cultural destruction.
threat: Chinese invasion (1959) and Cultural Revolution (1966-76). 6,000+ monasteries destroyed. Monks killed or forced to renounce.
quantity_lost: Unknown. Many monastery libraries completely destroyed.
saved_how: Monks fleeing to India carried texts. Dalai Lama established Library of Tibetan Works and Archives in Dharamsala (1970). Some texts memorized and reconstructed.
what_remains_at_risk: Tibetan Buddhism still suppressed in China. Oral lineages depend on aging teachers in exile.
sources: The Dragon in the Land of Snows (Tsering Shakya, 1999)

name: Iraqi Jewish Archive
driver_note: Discovered in flooded Mukhabarat (secret police) basement during US invasion. Originally seized from Iraqi Jews during 1970s-80s persecution.
threat: Flooding, neglect, looting during 2003 invasion. Archive was in intelligence headquarters basement with sewage water.
quantity_threatened: 2,700 Jewish books, tens of thousands of documents
quantity_lost: Some water damage, but most recovered.
saved_how: US forces discovered and evacuated archive. Freeze-dried and restored by National Archives in Washington. Digitized.
what_remains_at_risk: Diplomatic dispute over return to Iraq vs. giving to Jewish diaspora. Original community (150,000 in 1948) now ~4 people in Iraq.

name: Armenian Manuscripts (Matenadaran)
driver_note: Armenian Genocide targeted people and culture. Churches and manuscripts destroyed alongside population.
threat: Genocide destroyed Armenian churches, libraries, and cultural sites across Anatolia.
quantity_threatened: Unknown. Thousands of manuscripts in Armenian communities across Ottoman Empire.
quantity_lost: Many manuscripts in Anatolia destroyed with communities.
saved_how: Matenadaran collection in Yerevan (now 23,000+ manuscripts) preserved pre-genocide collection. Some manuscripts smuggled out by survivors.
what_remains_at_risk: Armenian heritage sites in Turkey deteriorating. No access for preservation.

name: Sarajevo Haggadah
driver_note: Same forces that destroyed National Library targeted Jewish and multi-ethnic heritage.
threat: Siege of Sarajevo. National Museum targeted. 14th-century illuminated Jewish manuscript at risk.
saved_how: Museum curator Enver Imamović and police officer hid it in bank vault under cover of darkness. Kept secret location until war ended.
what_remains_at_risk: Now displayed in Sarajevo. Symbolic of Bosnian multiculturalism that survived ethnic cleansing.

name: Polish Libraries (WWII)
driver_note: Nazi Generalplan Ost aimed to erase Polish culture. Libraries systematically destroyed.
threat: 16 million books destroyed. Warsaw libraries burned in 1944 uprising reprisal. Krasiński Library: 400,000 volumes burned.
saved_how: Underground libraries. Books hidden in walls, buried. Illegal lending networks. Some collections evacuated east.
what_remains_at_risk: 30% survived. Reconstruction ongoing. Some looted books still in Russian collections.
